October 2, 1961
Mr. Harold Hill
National Association of
Educational Broadcasters
1346 Connecticut Ave., N.W
Washington 6, D. C.
Dear Harold:
In response to your memo concerning committee reports, I feel
that it would be foolish for us to present a report from the re¬
search committee for the past year since we have really made no
contribution to the association.
At the last convention, Ken Harwood and I met with Bill
Harley and discussed some ideas which we had. We reiterated
these in a letter following the convention. These were ideas we
felt might promote more and better research among the educational
stations and other members. With the recent headquarters move and
the general uncertainty about the future, Bill felt that we ought
not move ahead with any of those at that time — which I certainly
understood.
We were represented at the recent Madison meeting and at the
advisory committee meeting for the survey of spectrum needs. How¬
ever, on the latter, just as with the McLuhan project, the committee
was informed about the NAEB*s involvement with the project after it
was so far underway that there was little constructive help possible.
Anyway, the point of all of this, is that we have nothing to
report.
Looking forward to seeing you in Washington.
Cordially,
SLB:mw
Samuel L. Becker
Director, Division of
Television-Radio-Film
